when_to_use: Newborns at birth or shortly after with poor tone, ineffective breathing, or bradycardia requiring resuscitation.

key_sections.summary: Assess tone, breathing, and heart rate. If term, good tone, and breathing/crying, provide routine care; otherwise, move to resuscitaire, provide warmth, and start initial steps.
Provide warmth, position airway, clear secretions only if obstructed, dry and stimulate. Reassess heart rate and breathing frequently.

If heart rate <100 bpm or inadequate breathing, start positive pressure ventilation with appropriately sized mask, aiming for visible chest rise and using room air or blended oxygen per local protocol.
If heart rate remains <60 bpm despite adequate ventilation, start chest compressions at 3:1 compression-to-ventilation ratio while continuing PPV.
For persistent bradycardia despite effective ventilation and compressions, consider adrenaline via umbilical venous access, correct hypovolaemia, and arrange ongoing neonatal intensive care.
